Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Workforce Creative thinking Assessment
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project focuses on designing exercises and developing a set of computational methods to measure and enhance semantic-based creativity in the workforce. When hiring a prospect or training an existing employee, there is no efficient way to measure one's problem solving abilities. In order to be an efficient problem solver, an employee must possess the knowledge (e.g., an employee is given a problem whose solution she has witnessed or contributed to previously) and the employee needs to think creatively (e.g., the employee encounters a novel problem; in most scenarios, creative employees use brainstorming methods to generate a number of possible solutions and test possible solutions to arrive at the best answer). This project's unique approach is the design of models, where creativity and divergent thinking is measured and a CQ index is generated.

Using advanced techniques in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and psychometric approach, the project evaluates the responses and generates an index called "Creativity Quotient," which represents users' creativity. The responses are evaluated based three factors: fluency (# of unique and relevant ideas), flexibility (# of categories of responses) & originality (infrequency and uniqueness of responses). The technique deploys a word or phrase-based associative weight where the algorithm measures the uniqueness of associations between words and phrases. Unique associations receive higher weighting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed phase I objectives were to:

  • Develop a scope to measure one's creative abilities and skillset
  • Test and gather data for validations using 500+ end-users; and
  • Validate the models using validation techniques such as Cronbach’s Alpha and Factor Analysis

To summarize our deliverables, we:

  • Designed and implemented two (2) creative thinking exercises;
  • Designed and implemented one (1) semantic-based psychometric system;
  • Designed and implemented one (1) creativity quotient modules (CQMs);
  • Designed and implemented two (2) rubrics for measuring one’s Storytelling and Linkage abilities;
  • Performed Criterion Validity – correlation between CQ, SAT, GRE, ACT, GPA, Storytelling Score, Linkage Score
  • Tested the module with over 1,100 alpha users;

To measure the Creativity Quotient (CQ), a semantics-based psychometric model has been created.  According to this model, one’s creative thinking abilities are measured based on four indices – Fluency, Flexibility, Originality and Elaboration.  Based on collaboration with our resident psychologist and subject-matter expert, a scaling factor for each index has been created:

  1. Fluency: # of unique and relevant responses - 1 – 1,000 (90th percentile > 900)
  2. Flexibility: # of distinct categories of responses - 1 – 1,000 (90th percentile > 900)
  3. Originality: Statistical infrequency of responses - 1 – 1,000 (90th percentile > 900
  4. Elaboration: Measure of details per each response - 1 – 1,000 (90th percentile > 900)

Two exercises named ResqueIt and ZomIt have been developed.  Each exercise measures one or more of the indices above.  We have used numerous reliability and validation techniques drawn from the psychometric approaches to conduct corresponding reliability and validity studies. They are Cronbach’s alpha for internal reliability, Factor Analysis for construct validity, and classical Pearson’s product-moment correlation for criterion validity.  

Correlation study between CQ measures and GPA; as part of this study, it was crucial to ensure that, we are not measuring one’s knowledge. Hence, we performed a quick study to measure the correlation between GPA and CQ measures (Originality, Flexibility, Fluency, Elaboration).  The Pearson-correlation between the SAT, GRE and ACT’s score and CQ measures are below 0.35; hence SparcIt’s dimensions do not measure or correlated with any of the standardized tests.

Correlation study between CQ measures and verbal section scores of SAT, GRE and ACT tests, which are known, though at the moderate levels, to predict communication skills of a person. The purpose of this study was to ensure that CQ measures are not just simply measure the communication skills, especially given the nature of the semantics-based methodology. Indeed, measures are computed in part based on the semantics-based text mining, hence creating a potential for a significant skew when CQ measures are computed. However, based on the result of the criterion validity study on creativity and communication, no significant skew was detected.
